@graph.rdfs:comment: Associates a neuron with the neurotransmitter system it participates in. This defines functional modulatory pathways including dopaminergic, serotonergic, cholinergic, and other neuromodulatory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: exhibits calcium dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron or synapse to its characteristic calcium dynamics patterns. Calcium dynamics regulate synaptic plasticity, gene expression, and numerous signaling pathways through spatiotemporal concentration changes.

@graph.rdfs:label: has refractory period
@graph.rdfs:comment: The minimum time interval between successive action potentials in a neuron, measured in milliseconds. Refractory periods are typically 1-5 milliseconds and determine maximum firing rates, with absolute refractory period due to sodium channel inactivation.

@graph.rdfs:label: has membrane time constant
@graph.rdfs:comment: The characteristic time scale for changes in membrane potential in response to input current, measured in milliseconds. Membrane time constants typically range from 5-50 milliseconds in neurons and determine temporal integration properties.

@graph.rdfs:label: has threshold voltage
@graph.rdfs:comment: The membrane potential value at which an action potential is triggered, measured in millivolts. Typical threshold values are -55 to -40 mV, determined by voltage-gated sodium channel activation kinetics.

@graph.rdfs:label: has firing rate
@graph.rdfs:comment: The average number of action potentials generated per unit time, typically measured in Hz (spikes per second). Firing rates encode stimulus intensity and other information, ranging from spontaneous rates of 1-5 Hz to maximal rates over 100 Hz.

@graph.rdfs:label: has synaptic weight
@graph.rdfs:comment: The strength or efficacy of a synaptic connection, determining how much influence presynaptic activity has on postsynaptic potential. Synaptic weights are modified during learning through plasticity mechanisms and can range from weak to strong connections.

@graph.rdfs:label: has Lyapunov exponent
@graph.rdfs:comment: A quantitative measure of the stability or chaos in a dynamical system. Positive Lyapunov exponents indicate chaotic dynamics with sensitive dependence on initial conditions, while negative values indicate stability and convergence to attractors.

@graph.rdfs:label: has conductance density
@graph.rdfs:comment: The number of ion channels per unit membrane area, measured in units like mS/cmÂ². Conductance density determines the strength of ionic currents in neurons and varies across different compartments and neuron types.

@graph.rdfs:label: has burst frequency
@graph.rdfs:comment: The rate at which burst events occur, measured in Hz. Burst frequency is distinct from intraburst spike frequency and encodes different stimulus features, typically ranging from 0.1 to 10 Hz depending on neuron type.

@graph.rdfs:label: has intraburst ISI
@graph.rdfs:comment: The interspike interval between action potentials within a burst, typically shorter than interburst intervals. Intraburst ISIs are often in the range of 2-10 milliseconds and determine burst density and information transmission reliability.

@graph.rdfs:label: has mutual information value
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the statistical dependence between neural responses and stimuli, quantifying how much information neural activity provides about the stimulus in bits. Mutual information provides a model-independent measure of coding efficiency.

@graph.rdfs:label: Leaky Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extension of the integrate-and-fire model that includes passive membrane leak current, making it more biologically realistic. The leak allows the membrane potential to decay to resting potential in the absence of input, providing a more accurate description of subthreshold integration.

@graph.rdfs:label: IF-FHN Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A hybrid model combining integrate-and-fire dynamics with FitzHugh-Nagumo nonlinear leak. This model shows increased sensitivity to correlated inputs compared to standard integrate-and-fire models due to nonlinear leakage term, bridging simplified and realistic neuron models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Two-Compartment Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuronal model consisting of somatic and dendritic compartments connected by coupling conductance. This minimal compartmental model captures soma-dendritic interactions important for burst generation, conditional backpropagation, and dendritic computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ghostburster Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A two-compartment reduced model of burst firing where the system passes near an infinite-period bifurcation. This model successfully reproduces burst firing observed in electrosensory pyramidal cells with minimal complexity, capturing essential burst dynamics through delay mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cable Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A model that treats neuronal processes as cylinders and uses cable equation to describe voltage propagation. Cable models capture the effects of cell geometry on electrical signal propagation in dendrites and axons, accounting for spatial attenuation and filtering.

@graph.rdfs:label: Multi-Compartmental Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: Detailed neuronal models that divide the cell into hundreds of compartments based on actual anatomy. These models can accurately simulate spatial distributions of ionic channels and complex dendritic integration, providing high-fidelity representations of real neurons.

@graph.rdfs:label: Delay Differential Equation Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A simplified burst model using discrete delays to mimic ping-pong effects between soma and dendrite. This computationally efficient model captures essential burst dynamics while remaining tractable for network simulations and analytical investigation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Covariance Rule
@graph.rdfs:comment: A Hebbian learning rule where synaptic changes depend on deviations of pre- and postsynaptic activities from their means. This rule prevents runaway potentiation while maintaining correlation-based learning, providing a more stable form of Hebbian plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sodium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Voltage-gated channels that mediate the rapid depolarizing phase of action potentials through Na+ influx. Sodium channels have fast activation and inactivation kinetics, are blocked by tetrodotoxin (TTX), and are essential for spike generation and propagation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Potassium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Voltage-gated channels responsible for repolarization and hyperpolarization during action potentials through K+ efflux. Multiple potassium channel subtypes (delayed rectifier, A-type, M-type, etc.) contribute to diverse neuronal properties and firing patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calcium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Voltage-gated channels that allow Ca2+ influx, triggering neurotransmitter release, gene expression, and various signaling cascades. Calcium channels include L-type, N-type, P/Q-type, and T-type subtypes with different voltage dependencies and kinetics.

@graph.rdfs:label: AptKv3.3 Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A high-voltage-activated potassium channel found in electrosensory pyramidal cells of weakly electric fish. This channel is distributed along the dendritic axis and modulates burst generation through cumulative inactivation, contributing to conditional backpropagation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cable Equation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A partial differential equation describing voltage propagation along neuronal processes, taking into account passive membrane properties and axial resistance. The cable equation is fundamental for understanding dendritic integration and spatial filtering of synaptic inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Nernst Equation
@graph.rdfs:comment: An equation that calculates the equilibrium potential for a specific ion across a membrane based on concentration gradients. The Nernst equation is fundamental for understanding resting potentials, reversal potentials, and the driving force for ion flow.

@graph.rdfs:label: Goldman Equation
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extension of the Nernst equation that accounts for multiple ion species and their relative permeabilities. The Goldman equation accurately predicts membrane potential when multiple ions contribute, providing a more realistic description than single-ion equations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Diffusion Equation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A partial differential equation describing how nitric oxide and other diffusible messengers spread through neural tissue. Analytical and numerical solutions to the diffusion equation are used to model volume transmission and gaseous signaling.

@graph.rdfs:label: Shannon Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the average uncertainty or entropy in a probability distribution, measured in bits. Shannon information quantifies the information content of neural spike trains and stimulus representations through entropy calculations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mutual Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the statistical dependence between two variables, quantifying how much information one variable provides about another. In neuroscience, mutual information quantifies stimulus-response relationships and provides model-independent coding efficiency metrics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fisher Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the amount of information a random variable carries about unknown parameters. In neural coding, Fisher information bounds the accuracy of stimulus estimation from neural responses through the Cramer-Rao inequality.

@graph.rdfs:label: Poisson Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A point process where events occur independently at a constant average rate. Poisson processes serve as baseline models for neural spike trains and are characterized by exponentially distributed interspike intervals and variance equal to mean count.

@graph.rdfs:label: Markov Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A stochastic process where future states depend only on the present state, not on past history. Markov processes are used to model ion channel gating, neural state transitions, and hidden state dynamics in neural systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gaussian Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A collection of random variables where any finite subset has a multivariate Gaussian distribution. Gaussian processes are used for receptive field estimation, adaptive filtering of neural data, and Bayesian nonparametric modeling.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hidden Markov Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical model where the system being modeled is assumed to be a Markov process with unobserved states. HMMs are used to analyze single ion channel recordings, decode neural states, and model sequence learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Diffusion Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A continuous-time stochastic process satisfying stochastic differential equations. Diffusion approximations are used to model noisy neuronal dynamics when synaptic input is highly irregular, as in balanced cortical networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Runge-Kutta Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: A family of iterative methods for numerically solving ordinary differential equations with higher accuracy than Euler method. Runge-Kutta methods (especially fourth-order RK4) are widely used in computational neuroscience for simulating neuronal dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Euler Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: A first-order numerical method for solving differential equations by linear approximation. While simple and fast, the Euler method has limited accuracy compared to higher-order methods and requires smaller time steps for stability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical method for estimating parameters by finding values that maximize the likelihood function. MLE has optimal asymptotic properties and is widely used for analyzing neural spike train data and fitting receptive field models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bayesian Inference
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical method that combines prior knowledge with observed data to make inferences about parameters. Bayesian methods are used for decoding neural activity, estimating receptive fields, and modeling perceptual decision-making.

@graph.rdfs:label: Series Expansion Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: A technique for estimating mutual information that corrects for sampling bias, particularly useful for sparsely responding neurons. This method allows rigorous analysis of spike timing information and population coding using series expansions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Maximum Likelihood Decoding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A method for estimating stimuli from neural responses by finding the stimulus that maximizes the likelihood of observed spikes. ML decoding provides optimal estimates under certain conditions and is used to assess neural code quality.

@graph.rdfs:label: Population Vector Decoding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A method for estimating continuous variables from population activity by computing a weighted vector sum of preferred directions. Population vectors are used to decode movement direction from motor cortex and have been influential in motor prosthetics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bayesian Decoding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A method combining prior knowledge with neural responses to estimate stimuli according to Bayes' rule. Bayesian decoding accounts for uncertainty and prior expectations, providing optimal estimates under probabilistic assumptions about neural codes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Attractor Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A recurrent neural network with multiple stable states corresponding to attractors in state space. Attractor networks implement associative memory, working memory, and decision-making through stable activity patterns sustained by recurrent connections.

@graph.rdfs:label: Recurrent Cortical Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A network model with extensive feedback connections characteristic of cortical circuits. Recurrent networks exhibit complex dynamics including persistent activity, oscillations, and multistability, implementing various computational functions.

@graph.rdfs:label: GasNet Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An abstract model incorporating gaseous neurotransmitter diffusion (like nitric oxide) into neural networks. GasNets explore functional roles of volume transmission and non-synaptic signaling in computation, providing alternatives to purely synaptic communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: Primary Visual Cortex (V1)
@graph.rdfs:comment: The first cortical area dedicated to processing visual information, containing neurons selective for oriented edges, motion direction, and spatial frequency. V1 is also called striate cortex due to its distinctive layered appearance and implements edge detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Secondary Visual Cortex (V2)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A visual cortical area that processes more complex features than V1, including illusory contours, texture, and object boundaries. V2 receives strong input from V1 and projects to higher visual areas for object recognition.

@graph.rdfs:label: Visual Area V4
@graph.rdfs:comment: An intermediate visual area involved in color processing, shape representation, and visual attention. V4 neurons show attention-dependent modulation of responses and contribute to figure-ground segregation and object recognition.

@graph.rdfs:label: Middle Temporal Area (MT)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A visual area specialized for motion processing, containing neurons selective for direction and speed of motion. MT is crucial for motion perception and visuomotor control, with microstimulation experiments demonstrating causal roles in perception.

@graph.rdfs:label: Somatosensory Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: Cortical regions processing touch, proprioception, and pain information. Somatosensory cortex contains topographic maps of the body surface (homunculus) and implements hierarchical processing of tactile features.

@graph.rdfs:label: Motor Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: Cortical regions involved in planning, control, and execution of voluntary movements. Motor cortex includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, and supplementary motor area, each with distinct roles in motor control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Entorhinal Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brain region serving as the main interface between hippocampus and neocortex, containing grid cells that encode spatial location. Entorhinal cortex is crucial for spatial navigation, memory, and temporal coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Subiculum
@graph.rdfs:comment: The major output structure of hippocampus, receiving input from CA1 and projecting to entorhinal cortex and subcortical structures. Subiculum neurons can exhibit burst firing driven by dendritic calcium spikes and implement spatiotemporal transformations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Amygdala
@graph.rdfs:comment: A medial temporal lobe structure involved in emotional processing, particularly fear and reward learning. Amygdala has extensive connections with cortex, hippocampus, and hypothalamus, implementing emotional valence assignments.

@graph.rdfs:label: Thalamus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A central diencephalic structure serving as a relay and modulator of information between sensory systems and cortex. Thalamic neurons exhibit distinct burst and tonic firing modes controlled by T-type calcium channels.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hypothalamus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A diencephalic structure controlling homeostatic functions including hormone release, autonomic control, and motivated behaviors. Hypothalamus contains distinct nuclei with specialized functions and regulates pituitary hormone secretion.

@graph.rdfs:label: Brainstem
@graph.rdfs:comment: The posterior part of the brain connecting to spinal cord, controlling vital autonomic functions and containing numerous cranial nerve nuclei. Brainstem includes medulla, pons, and midbrain, implementing basic sensorimotor reflexes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spinal Cord
@graph.rdfs:comment: The caudal part of the central nervous system mediating sensory-motor reflexes and transmitting signals between brain and periphery. Spinal cord contains central pattern generators for locomotion and reflexive motor control circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Lobula Plate
@graph.rdfs:comment: A region in the fly visual system containing large tangential cells that integrate local motion signals for optomotor control. Lobula plate neurons are selective for specific patterns of optic flow and implement correlation-based motion detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Optic Lobe
@graph.rdfs:comment: The visual processing center in insects, containing multiple retinotopic maps and motion detection circuitry. Optic lobe includes lamina, medulla, lobula, and lobula plate implementing hierarchical visual processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Electrosensory Lateral Line Lobe (ELL)
@graph.rdfs:comment: The first central processing stage for electrosensory information in weakly electric fish, containing pyramidal cells that exhibit burst firing. ELL implements feature extraction, adaptive filtering, and predictive coding of electrosensory inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pyramidal Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: The most common excitatory neuron type in cortex and hippocampus, characterized by pyramid-shaped soma and extensive apical dendrite. Pyramidal neurons use glutamate as neurotransmitter and can exhibit various firing patterns including bursting.

@graph.rdfs:label: Basket Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A type of GABAergic interneuron that forms basket-like synaptic contacts around soma of target neurons. Basket cells are fast-spiking and important for gamma oscillations, providing powerful perisomatic inhibition.

@graph.rdfs:label: Stellate Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Neurons with star-shaped dendritic arbors found in cortex, cerebellum, and other regions. Stellate cells can be excitatory (spiny stellate) or inhibitory depending on location and provide local circuit processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Retinal Ganglion Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Output neurons of the retina whose axons form the optic nerve and transmit visual information to brain. Retinal ganglion cells are selective for features like edges, motion, and color contrast through center-surround receptive fields.

@graph.rdfs:label: Motor Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Neurons that directly innervate muscles and control movement. Motor neurons integrate synaptic input from premotor circuits and exhibit rate-coding properties correlating with muscle force, implementing the final common pathway.

@graph.rdfs:label: Place Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Hippocampal pyramidal neurons that fire selectively when an animal occupies specific locations in an environment. Place cells form a cognitive map of space and are fundamental to spatial navigation and episodic memory.

@graph.rdfs:label: Grid Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Entorhinal neurons that fire when an animal occupies vertices of a repeating hexagonal grid covering the environment. Grid cells provide a metric for spatial coding and contribute to path integration through continuous attractor dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bipolar Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Retinal neurons that connect photoreceptors to ganglion cells, implementing center-surround receptive fields. Bipolar cells can be ON-type (depolarizing to light) or OFF-type (hyperpolarizing to light).

@graph.rdfs:label: Chattering Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Cortical pyramidal neurons in superficial layers that fire high-frequency bursts (30-70 Hz) in response to depolarization. Chattering neurons may contribute to gamma oscillations in cortex through resonant burst firing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Regular-Spiking Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Cortical pyramidal neurons that fire trains of action potentials with frequency adaptation in response to sustained input. Regular-spiking neurons are the most common excitatory cell type in cortex, implementing spike-frequency adaptation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fast-Spiking Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Cortical GABAergic interneurons (typically basket cells) that can sustain high firing rates without adaptation. Fast-spiking neurons provide powerful inhibition and contribute to network oscillations through rapid spiking.

@graph.rdfs:label: Tangential Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Large neurons in the fly lobula plate with extensive dendritic fields that integrate local motion signals. Different tangential cells are selective for different patterns of optic flow, implementing wide-field motion detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mitral Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Principal output neurons of olfactory bulb that receive input from olfactory receptor neurons in glomeruli. Mitral cells exhibit synchronized oscillatory activity and lateral inhibition through granule cells.

@graph.rdfs:label: Vasopressin Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Hypothalamic magnocellular neurons that synthesize and release vasopressin hormone. These neurons exhibit phasic burst firing patterns that optimize hormone release from the posterior pituitary for water balance regulation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Oxytocin Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: Hypothalamic magnocellular neurons that release oxytocin hormone involved in social bonding, lactation, and parturition. Oxytocin neurons can exhibit synchronized burst firing during milk ejection reflex.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dopamine Neurotransmitter
@graph.rdfs:comment: A catecholamine neurotransmitter involved in reward, motivation, motor control, and cognition. Dopamine dysfunction is implicated in Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, and addiction, with distinct roles in different projection systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Glutamate Neurotransmitter
@graph.rdfs:comment: The primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain, acting on AMPA, NMDA, and metabotropic receptors. Glutamate mediates fast synaptic transmission and is crucial for learning and memory, though excitotoxic at high levels.

@graph.rdfs:label: Acetylcholine Neurotransmitter
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neurotransmitter at neuromuscular junctions and throughout the brain, involved in attention, arousal, and memory. Cholinergic dysfunction contributes to Alzheimer's disease and age-related cognitive decline.

@graph.rdfs:label: Serotonin (5-HT)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A monoamine neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation, sleep, appetite, and cognition. Serotonergic drugs including SSRIs are widely used as antidepressants, modulating mood and emotional processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Vasopressin Peptide
@graph.rdfs:comment: A peptide hormone released from hypothalamus that regulates water balance and social behavior. Vasopressin is synthesized in magnocellular neurons and released from posterior pituitary in response to osmotic and cardiovascular signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: Oxytocin Peptide
@graph.rdfs:comment: A peptide hormone involved in social bonding, trust, lactation, and parturition. Oxytocin is synthesized in hypothalamic neurons and acts both as hormone and neuromodulator in social behavior circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Saddle-Node Bifurcation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A bifurcation where a stable and unstable fixed point collide and annihilate. Saddle-node bifurcations characterize Type I neural excitability, continuous F-I curves, and transitions from quiescence to tonic firing at arbitrary low frequencies.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hopf Bifurcation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A bifurcation where a fixed point loses stability and a limit cycle is born. Hopf bifurcations characterize Type II neural excitability, discontinuous F-I curves, and the onset of oscillations with finite frequency.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fixed-Point Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A stable equilibrium state toward which a dynamical system evolves from nearby initial conditions. In neurons, fixed-point attractors correspond to resting potential or stable depolarized states in working memory networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Limit-Cycle Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A closed trajectory in phase space corresponding to periodic oscillations that are robust to perturbations. In neurons, limit cycles represent repetitive spiking or burst oscillations generated by nonlinear feedback.

@graph.rdfs:label: Strange Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A fractal attractor associated with chaotic dynamics and sensitive dependence on initial conditions. Strange attractors have positive Lyapunov exponents and exhibit complex temporal patterns in neural systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Type I Neuron Excitability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Neural excitability characterized by continuous F-I curves where neurons can fire at arbitrarily low frequencies near threshold. Type I excitability arises from saddle-node bifurcations, as in integrate-and-fire models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Type II Neuron Excitability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Neural excitability characterized by discontinuous F-I curves with a minimum firing frequency. Type II excitability arises from Hopf bifurcations, as in the Hodgkin-Huxley model, and favors synchronization.

@graph.rdfs:label: Conditional Backpropagation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mechanism where action potential backpropagation into dendrites depends on spike frequency and dendritic refractory period. Conditional backpropagation underlies burst generation in electrosensory pyramidal cells through frequency-dependent dendritic spike initiation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ping-Pong Mechanism
@graph.rdfs:comment: A burst generation mechanism involving reciprocal interactions between soma and dendrite, where current sources back into soma after dendritic spikes. This mechanism is found in various burst-firing neurons including pyramidal cells.

@graph.rdfs:label: Persistent Sodium Current
@graph.rdfs:comment: A slowly inactivating or non-inactivating sodium current active at subthreshold potentials. Persistent sodium current contributes to burst generation, membrane bistability, and sustained depolarization in various neuron types.

@graph.rdfs:label: Low-Threshold Calcium Current (T-type)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A calcium current activated at relatively hyperpolarized potentials and important for burst firing in thalamic neurons. T-type calcium channels require hyperpolarization for de-inactivation and mediate rebound bursts.

@graph.rdfs:label: Afterhyperpolarization (AHP) Current
@graph.rdfs:comment: Hyperpolarizing currents following action potentials or spike trains, typically mediated by calcium-activated potassium channels. AHP regulates firing rate, produces spike-frequency adaptation, and terminates bursts.

@graph.rdfs:label: Temporal Coding Scheme
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where information is carried by precise spike timing rather than just firing rate. Temporal codes can convey more information than rate codes in the same time window through mechanisms like phase locking and synchrony.

@graph.rdfs:label: Rate Coding Scheme
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where information is represented by the average firing rate of neurons over time windows. Rate coding has been the traditional view of neural coding, robust to noise but slower than temporal codes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spike Timing Code
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme based on precise temporal relationships between spikes, either within single neurons or across populations. Spike timing codes can emerge from synaptic dynamics and temporal integration windows.

@graph.rdfs:label: Coincidence Detection
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural mechanism sensitive to temporally synchronized inputs, implemented through short membrane time constants or specific channel properties. Coincidence detection is important for sound localization and temporal coding in auditory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Correlation Detector
@graph.rdfs:comment: A motion detection mechanism that multiplies delayed versions of signals from neighboring spatial locations. Correlation detectors are fundamental to fly motion vision and implement the Reichardt model of motion detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Saliency Map
@graph.rdfs:comment: A topographic representation of visual salience that guides attention to behaviorally relevant locations. Saliency maps combine bottom-up feature information to create a master map for attention deployment in visual search.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spatial Summation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Integration of synaptic inputs across different spatial locations on a neuron. Spatial summation can be linear or nonlinear depending on dendritic properties, cable attenuation, and active conductances.

@graph.rdfs:label: Temporal Summation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Integration of synaptic inputs arriving at different times, allowing subthreshold inputs to accumulate and reach firing threshold. Temporal summation depends on membrane time constant and synaptic kinetics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cortical Layer 2/3
@graph.rdfs:comment: Superficial cortical layers containing pyramidal neurons that form horizontal connections within and between cortical areas. Layer 2/3 integrates information across cortical columns and implements associative connections.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cortical Layer 4
@graph.rdfs:comment: The primary input layer of sensory cortex receiving thalamocortical projections. Layer 4 contains spiny stellate cells and granule cells that distribute sensory information to other cortical layers.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cortical Layer 5
@graph.rdfs:comment: A deep cortical layer containing large pyramidal neurons that project to subcortical structures including thalamus, superior colliculus, and spinal cord. Layer 5 is the main output layer for motor and long-range projections.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cortical Layer 6
@graph.rdfs:comment: The deepest cortical layer containing pyramidal neurons that project back to thalamus, providing corticothalamic feedback. Layer 6 modulates thalamic relay and implements gain control of sensory inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Striatum
@graph.rdfs:comment: The input nucleus of the basal ganglia receiving cortical and thalamic projections. Striatum contains medium spiny neurons and implements action selection, habit formation, and reinforcement learning through dopamine-dependent plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Substantia Nigra
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain structure containing dopaminergic neurons that project to striatum and modulate motor control. Degeneration of substantia nigra dopamine neurons causes Parkinson's disease.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain region containing dopaminergic neurons that project to prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens. VTA implements reward prediction error signals critical for reinforcement learning and motivation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Nucleus Accumbens
@graph.rdfs:comment: A ventral striatal structure involved in reward processing, motivation, and addiction. Nucleus accumbens receives dopaminergic input from VTA and integrates limbic and motor information.

@graph.rdfs:label: Superior Colliculus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain structure involved in saccadic eye movements and orienting responses. Superior colliculus contains topographic motor maps and integrates multisensory information for gaze control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Inferior Colliculus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain nucleus that processes auditory information and computes sound localization. Inferior colliculus integrates binaural cues and projects to auditory thalamus.

@graph.rdfs:label: Locus Ceruleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brainstem nucleus containing noradrenergic neurons that project throughout the brain. Locus ceruleus regulates arousal, attention, and stress responses through widespread norepinephrine release.

@graph.rdfs:label: Raphe Nuclei
@graph.rdfs:comment: Brainstem nuclei containing serotonergic neurons that project to forebrain. Raphe nuclei regulate mood, sleep, and arousal through serotonin release and are targets of antidepressant drugs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Nucleus Basalis
@graph.rdfs:comment: A basal forebrain nucleus containing cholinergic neurons that project to cortex and hippocampus. Nucleus basalis regulates attention, arousal, and cortical plasticity through acetylcholine release.

@graph.rdfs:label: Superior Olive
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brainstem auditory nucleus that processes binaural information for sound localization. Superior olive neurons act as coincidence detectors comparing interaural time and level differences.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cochlear Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: The first central auditory processing station receiving input from cochlear nerve. Cochlear nucleus performs initial feature extraction of auditory signals including onset detection and frequency analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: Red Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain motor nucleus involved in limb movement control and motor learning. Red nucleus receives cerebellar input and projects to spinal cord for motor coordination.

@graph.rdfs:label: Deep Cerebellar Nuclei
@graph.rdfs:comment: Output nuclei of cerebellum including dentate, interpositus, and fastigial nuclei. Deep cerebellar nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from mossy and climbing fibers.

@graph.rdfs:label: Inferior Olive
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brainstem nucleus providing climbing fiber input to cerebellum. Inferior olive neurons exhibit synchronized oscillations and signal error or surprise for motor learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN)
@graph.rdfs:comment: The thalamic relay nucleus for visual information projecting to primary visual cortex. LGN has six layers with distinct receptive field properties and implements gain control of visual signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: Medial Geniculate Body
@graph.rdfs:comment: The thalamic relay nucleus for auditory information projecting to auditory cortex. Medial geniculate body processes tonotopic and temporal features of sound.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ventral Posterior Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: The thalamic relay nucleus for somatosensory information projecting to somatosensory cortex. Ventral posterior nucleus maintains somatotopic organization and relays touch and proprioception.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pulvinar Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A higher-order thalamic nucleus involved in visual attention and cortico-cortical communication. Pulvinar coordinates activity between visual cortical areas and modulates attentional selection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reticular Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A shell of GABAergic neurons surrounding thalamus that regulates thalamic relay. Reticular nucleus implements gain control, attention, and sleep spindles through inhibitory connections.

@graph.rdfs:label: Interpeduncular Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A midbrain structure receiving input from habenula and involved in stress responses and aversion. Interpeduncular nucleus contains diverse neurotransmitter systems and modulates motivation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Wilson-Cowan Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A rate-based network model describing dynamics of excitatory and inhibitory neural populations. Wilson-Cowan model exhibits oscillations, bistability, and pattern formation in recurrent networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hopfield Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A recurrent neural network model with symmetric connections implementing associative memory through energy minimization. Hopfield networks store patterns as attractors and perform pattern completion.

@graph.rdfs:label: Boltzmann Machine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A stochastic recurrent neural network that learns probability distributions over binary patterns. Boltzmann machines use simulated annealing and can model statistical structure in data.

@graph.rdfs:label: Liquid State Machine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A reservoir computing model where a recurrent network of spiking neurons transforms temporal inputs into high-dimensional representations. Liquid state machines implement universal computation through readout from transient dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Echo State Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A reservoir computing model with randomly connected rate units and trained readout. Echo state networks efficiently learn temporal patterns and dynamical systems through fixed recurrent weights.

@graph.rdfs:label: Self-Organizing Map
@graph.rdfs:comment: An unsupervised neural network that learns topographic representations of input space through competitive learning. Self-organizing maps model cortical map formation and dimensionality reduction.

@graph.rdfs:label: Restricted Boltzmann Machine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A generative neural network with bipartite architecture learning probability distributions. Restricted Boltzmann machines can be stacked to form deep belief networks for unsupervised feature learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Convolutional Neural Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A deep learning architecture with local connectivity, weight sharing, and pooling inspired by visual cortex. Convolutional neural networks excel at image recognition through hierarchical feature extraction.

@graph.rdfs:label: Recurrent Neural Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural network with feedback connections enabling temporal processing and memory. Recurrent neural networks model sequential data and implement dynamical computation through hidden state evolution.

@graph.rdfs:label: Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A recurrent neural network with gating mechanisms that can learn long-term temporal dependencies. LSTM networks overcome vanishing gradients through memory cells and multiplicative gates.

@graph.rdfs:label: Izhikevich Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A two-dimensional spiking neuron model that reproduces diverse firing patterns with computational efficiency. Izhikevich model combines biological realism with mathematical tractability through quadratic voltage dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Adaptive Exponential Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A generalized integrate-and-fire model with exponential spike generation and adaptation current. AdEx model captures spike initiation dynamics and firing patterns with few parameters.

@graph.rdfs:label: Quadratic Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An integrate-and-fire variant with quadratic voltage dependence exhibiting Type I excitability. Quadratic IF model approximates saddle-node bifurcation and canonical theta neuron dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Theta Neuron Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A phase model representing Type I neurons on a circle, derived from quadratic integrate-and-fire. Theta neurons are canonical models for studying synchronization and collective dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Morris-Lecar Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A two-variable conductance-based model describing voltage oscillations in barnacle muscle. Morris-Lecar model is widely used for bifurcation analysis and exhibits both Type I and Type II excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hindmarsh-Rose Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A three-variable model capturing bursting and chaotic dynamics in neurons. Hindmarsh-Rose model exhibits diverse bifurcations and complex temporal patterns including chaos.

@graph.rdfs:label: Connor-Stevens Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extension of Hodgkin-Huxley model with A-type potassium current that produces spike frequency adaptation. Connor-Stevens model captures transient potassium currents important for repetitive firing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Traub Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A detailed multi-compartment model of hippocampal pyramidal cells with numerous active conductances. Traub models reproduce intrinsic burst firing, dendritic spikes, and network oscillations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Wang-Buzsaki Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A simplified conductance-based model of fast-spiking interneurons used in network studies. Wang-Buzsaki model captures high-frequency firing and is computationally efficient for network simulations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Perfect Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An integrate-and-fire model without leak current where voltage strictly integrates input. Perfect IF model is analytically tractable and exhibits infinite memory of past inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Exponential Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An IF model with exponential spike generation mechanism capturing action potential initiation. Exponential IF provides better match to biological spike onset dynamics than linear threshold.

@graph.rdfs:label: Resetting Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A generic spiking neuron model defined by spike times and reset conditions. Resetting models provide abstract frameworks for studying spike-timing codes independent of subthreshold dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spike Response Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron model representing voltage as a convolution of input with kernel functions. Spike response models provide generalized frameworks for integrate-and-fire dynamics with history dependence.

@graph.rdfs:label: Generalized Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An IF model with adaptive threshold and multiple timescales capturing spike-frequency adaptation. Generalized IF unifies various IF variants through threshold dynamics and adaptation currents.

@graph.rdfs:label: BCM Plasticity Rule
@graph.rdfs:comment: A synaptic plasticity rule with sliding threshold that implements stability and selectivity. BCM (Bienenstock-Cooper-Munro) rule explains development of orientation selectivity through rate-based Hebbian learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Oja's Learning Rule
@graph.rdfs:comment: A stabilized Hebbian rule with weight normalization that performs principal component analysis. Oja's rule extracts the first principal component through unsupervised learning with weight decay.

@graph.rdfs:label: Homeostatic Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Slow adaptive mechanisms that maintain neural activity within operational ranges through global scaling. Homeostatic plasticity counterbalances Hebbian learning and prevents runaway excitation or silencing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Metaplasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Plasticity of synaptic plasticity where the modification threshold depends on prior activity history. Metaplasticity implements sliding thresholds for LTP/LTD induction, stabilizing learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Short-Term Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Activity-dependent changes in synaptic strength on timescales of milliseconds to seconds. Short-term plasticity includes facilitation and depression, implementing temporal filters and gain control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synaptic Scaling
@graph.rdfs:comment: A form of homeostatic plasticity that multiplies all synaptic weights by a common factor to regulate overall excitability. Synaptic scaling maintains relative synaptic strengths while controlling firing rates.

@graph.rdfs:label: Triplet STDP Rule
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extension of STDP that depends on spike triplets, capturing frequency-dependent plasticity. Triplet STDP explains BCM-like behavior and the dependence of plasticity on spike rate.

@graph.rdfs:label: Voltage-Based STDP
@graph.rdfs:comment: A plasticity rule depending on postsynaptic voltage rather than spikes, implementing graded learning. Voltage-based STDP provides biophysical mechanisms for spike-timing-dependent learning through calcium dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reward-Modulated STDP
@graph.rdfs:comment: A three-factor learning rule where STDP is gated by reward signals like dopamine. Reward-modulated STDP implements reinforcement learning in spiking networks through eligibility traces.

@graph.rdfs:label: Structural Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Formation and elimination of synapses and dendritic spines on longer timescales. Structural plasticity reorganizes connectivity patterns and underlies circuit refinement during development and learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Place Field Remapping
@graph.rdfs:comment: Rapid reorganization of hippocampal place cell responses in different environments or contexts. Remapping demonstrates fast reconfiguration of spatial representations through attractor dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Somatic-Dendritic Interaction
@graph.rdfs:comment: Bidirectional communication between soma and dendrites involving action potential backpropagation and dendritic spikes. Soma-dendrite coupling generates burst firing and implements coincidence detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dendritic Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Local action potentials initiated in dendrites through sodium, calcium, or NMDA currents. Dendritic spikes amplify synaptic inputs and trigger burst firing through soma-dendrite interactions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calcium Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Dendritic action potentials mediated by voltage-gated calcium channels with slower kinetics. Calcium spikes amplify synaptic input, trigger neurotransmitter release, and induce plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: NMDA Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Dendritic regenerative events mediated by NMDA receptors through voltage-dependent magnesium unblock. NMDA spikes implement local nonlinear integration of clustered synaptic inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Plateau Potential
@graph.rdfs:comment: Sustained depolarizations lasting hundreds of milliseconds mediated by persistent inward currents. Plateau potentials implement bistability and working memory in motor neurons and prefrontal cortex.

@graph.rdfs:label: Action Potential Backpropagation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Retrograde propagation of somatic spikes into dendritic arbors, modulated by active conductances. Backpropagation provides postsynaptic signals for STDP and dendritic integration.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sodium Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Fast action potentials mediated primarily by voltage-gated sodium channels in soma and axon. Sodium spikes propagate reliably and rapidly, implementing neural communication over long distances.

@graph.rdfs:label: Axonal Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Action potentials initiated in axon initial segment with high sodium channel density. Axonal spikes typically have lower thresholds than somatic spikes and propagate orthodromically.

@graph.rdfs:label: Complex Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Multi-spiked responses in Purkinje cells triggered by climbing fiber input with calcium-mediated components. Complex spikes signal errors for motor learning and modulate simple spike firing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Simple Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Regular sodium-mediated action potentials in Purkinje cells driven by parallel fiber input. Simple spikes represent cerebellar output and encode movement parameters through rate modulation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fast Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Brief action potentials with rapid depolarization and repolarization characteristic of interneurons. Fast spikes enable high-frequency firing and precise temporal control of network activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gamma Oscillation (30-80 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Fast network oscillations generated by interactions between excitatory and inhibitory neurons. Gamma oscillations coordinate neural activity, implement attention, and support information binding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Beta Oscillation (15-30 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Mid-frequency oscillations prominent in motor cortex and basal ganglia during movement preparation. Beta oscillations are modulated by dopamine and implicated in Parkinson's disease.

@graph.rdfs:label: Alpha Oscillation (8-12 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Prominent oscillations in posterior cortex during relaxed wakefulness and visual inattention. Alpha oscillations implement functional inhibition and are modulated by attention.

@graph.rdfs:label: Theta Oscillation (4-8 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Rhythmic activity in hippocampus during exploration and memory encoding, coordinating place cell firing. Theta oscillations implement temporal coding through phase precession.

@graph.rdfs:label: Delta Oscillation (1-4 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Slow oscillations prominent during deep sleep and characterized by alternating Up and Down states. Delta oscillations coordinate cortical plasticity and memory consolidation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sleep Spindle (12-15 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: Transient oscillatory bursts during non-REM sleep generated by thalamocortical circuits. Sleep spindles are associated with memory consolidation and synaptic plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sharp-Wave Ripple (150-250 Hz)
@graph.rdfs:comment: High-frequency oscillations in hippocampus during rest and sleep associated with memory replay. Sharp-wave ripples coordinate information transfer to neocortex for memory consolidation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Up-Down State Oscillation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Bistable transitions between active (Up) and quiescent (Down) states in cortical networks during sleep and anesthesia. Up-Down states implement memory consolidation through repeated pattern replay.

@graph.rdfs:label: Traveling Wave
@graph.rdfs:comment: Spatially propagating patterns of neural activity observed across cortex and other structures. Traveling waves coordinate timing across brain regions and implement sequential processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synchronized State
@graph.rdfs:comment: Collective network state where neurons fire in phase, emerging through excitatory coupling or common input. Synchronization implements information binding and can arise through various mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Asynchronous Irregular State
@graph.rdfs:comment: Network state with irregular uncorrelated firing resembling cortex during active processing. Asynchronous states arise from balanced excitation and inhibition, maximizing information capacity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Balanced State
@graph.rdfs:comment: Network regime where excitation and inhibition track each other, generating irregular firing. Balanced states explain cortical variability and enable sensitive response to weak inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Critical State
@graph.rdfs:comment: Network operating near phase transition with power-law statistics and maximal information processing. Critical states optimize dynamic range and information transmission in neural systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gabor Filter
@graph.rdfs:comment: A linear receptive field model combining Gaussian envelope with sinusoidal carrier, resembling simple cell receptive fields. Gabor filters are optimal for joint localization in space and spatial frequency.

@graph.rdfs:label: Difference of Gaussians (DoG)
@graph.rdfs:comment: A center-surround receptive field model using difference of two Gaussian functions. DoG filters approximate Laplacian of Gaussian and model retinal ganglion cell receptive fields.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reichardt Detector
@graph.rdfs:comment: A correlation-based motion detection mechanism multiplying delayed signals from adjacent locations. Reichardt detectors are fundamental to insect motion vision and implement elementary motion detection.

@graph.rdfs:label: Energy Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A model of complex cell responses combining quadrature pairs of simple cells in visual cortex. Energy models capture phase invariance and direction selectivity through spatiotemporal filtering.

@graph.rdfs:label: Divisive Normalization
@graph.rdfs:comment: A canonical neural computation dividing responses by pooled activity for gain control. Normalization explains contrast adaptation, attention effects, and surround suppression across sensory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Predictive Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A hierarchical processing framework where higher areas predict lower area activity and errors are propagated upward. Predictive coding implements efficient coding and Bayesian inference in cortical hierarchies.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sparse Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding strategy where only a small fraction of neurons are active at any time, minimizing metabolic cost. Sparse coding maximizes information capacity and emerges from unsupervised learning of natural statistics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Grandmother Cell Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extreme sparse coding scheme where single neurons represent complex concepts or specific individuals. Grandmother cells provide invariant representations but lack robustness to neuron loss.

@graph.rdfs:label: Coarse Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A population coding strategy with broadly tuned neurons and overlapping receptive fields. Coarse coding achieves fine discrimination through population averaging despite individual neuron imprecision.

@graph.rdfs:label: Place Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where information is read from the identity of active neurons rather than their rate. Place coding is efficient for sparse representations and underlies labeled line theories.

@graph.rdfs:label: Phase Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A temporal coding scheme where spike timing relative to network oscillations carries information. Phase coding is prominent in hippocampal place cells through theta phase precession.

@graph.rdfs:label: Latency Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where information is carried by response latency or time-to-first-spike. Latency coding enables rapid processing and is observed in early sensory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synchrony Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where coincident firing of neuron groups represents features or binds features into objects. Synchrony coding implements dynamic grouping through temporal correlation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Rank Order Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme based on the temporal order of first spikes in a population. Rank order coding enables ultrafast processing within single wave of activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Interspike Interval Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A coding scheme where information is carried by intervals between successive spikes. ISI coding can encode stimulus features beyond firing rate alone.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synfire Chain
@graph.rdfs:comment: A feedforward network architecture propagating synchronous volleys of spikes. Synfire chains implement precise temporal sequences and rapid signal propagation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Winner-Take-All Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A competitive network where lateral inhibition selects the most active neuron or group. Winner-take-all implements decision making, attention, and sparse coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Continuous Attractor Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: An attractor network with a continuum of stable states forming manifolds in state space. Continuous attractors implement working memory with graded representations and head direction cells.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ring Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A continuous attractor with ring topology modeling head direction cells and motor planning. Ring attractors maintain angular representations through Mexican-hat connectivity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bump Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A continuous attractor with localized activity bumps that can be moved by external input. Bump attractors model working memory, spatial representations, and eye position integration.

@graph.rdfs:label: Line Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A continuous attractor with one-dimensional manifold of stable states. Line attractors implement neural integrators for eye position, motor planning, and decision variables.

@graph.rdfs:label: Discrete Attractor Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: An attractor network with finite number of stable states representing discrete memories or categories. Discrete attractors implement associative memory and decision making.

@graph.rdfs:label: Perceptron
@graph.rdfs:comment: A single-layer feedforward network with linear weighted sum and threshold. Perceptrons learn linearly separable classifications through supervised learning rules.

@graph.rdfs:label: Backpropagation Algorithm
@graph.rdfs:comment: A supervised learning algorithm propagating errors backward through network layers to adjust weights. Backpropagation enables training of multi-layer neural networks through gradient descent.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hebbian Learning Algorithm
@graph.rdfs:comment: An unsupervised learning rule strengthening connections between coactive neurons. Hebbian learning extracts correlations and forms cell assemblies without external supervision.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reinforcement Learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: A learning paradigm where agents learn optimal actions through trial and error guided by reward signals. Reinforcement learning models dopaminergic systems and goal-directed behavior in biological neural networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Unsupervised Learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: A learning approach that discovers structure and patterns in data without explicit labels or supervision. Unsupervised learning models cortical self-organization, feature extraction, and dimensionality reduction in sensory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Temporal Difference Learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: A reinforcement learning method that learns value functions by comparing predictions at successive time steps. Temporal difference learning models dopamine neuron responses and reward prediction errors in basal ganglia circuits.
